question: What are the obligations of a Mining Reporting Entity when a Prospectus includes statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves, or Production Targets, and how do these relate to sustainable operating practices?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure that any Prospectus including statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves, or Production Targets complies with Rule 11.2.1, as well as the requirements of Chapter 4 [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9]. Additionally, the disclosure must adhere to a Mining Reporting Standard and the relevant chapter [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]. The Prospectus must also detail the Mining Reporting Entity's policies and practices regarding sustainable operations, including their environmental and social policies, the impact of their business practices on the environment and communities, and the environmental and social risks they face [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9].

debug_context.source_text: In addition to complying with the requirements of Chapter 4, a Prospectus: (1) that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, must comply with Rule 11.2.1; and (2) must include details in relation to the Mining Reporting Entitys policies and practices in relation to operating in a sustainable manner, including: (i) the Mining Reporting Entitys policy with regards to environmental and social issues; (ii) impact of the Mining Reporting Entitys business practices on the environment and the communities in which it operates; and (iii) the environmental and social risks faced by the Mining Reporting Entity.
debug_context.target_text: Requirements for all disclosures. A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets must be prepared in accordance with: (1) a Mining Reporting Standard; and (2) this chapter.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator initiate an investigation into the business of an Authorised Person, and how does a request by a Non-ADGM Regulator influence this process?
expected_answer: The Regulator is empowered to initiate an investigation into the business of an Authorised Person if there is a good reason to do so. This includes examining the nature, conduct, or state of the business, a specific aspect of it, or the ownership or control of the Authorised Person [#SRC:c12ad91e-5b46-46c8-aa05-fd73299e8675]. Additionally, an investigation may be commenced if a Non-ADGM Regulator requests it under section 217, provided there is a reasonable basis for the request [#TGT:9c4e6686-4ca1-4a0e-b3b6-7488a81c9c2c].

debug_context.target_text: If it appears to the Regulator that there is good reason for doing so, the Regulator may commence an investigation into— (a) the nature, conduct or state of the Business of an Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Remote Body; (b) a particular aspect of that Business; (c) the ownership or control of an Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Remote Body; or (d) a matter reasonably requested to be investigated pursuant to a request made under section ‎217.

question: What are the procedural requirements for an Authorised Person seeking FSRA approval to use a new Virtual Asset, and how does the Regulator determine if the Virtual Asset meets the criteria of an Accepted Virtual Asset?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person intending to use a new Virtual Asset, beyond those initially approved, must first obtain approval from the FSRA. This requires submitting a written application containing all pertinent information about the Virtual Asset, including existing or proposed risk management controls [#SRC:ee620070-0c48-454c-9530-0b3abf34c142]. The FSRA will assess whether the Virtual Asset qualifies as an Accepted Virtual Asset by considering factors such as a maturity or market capitalisation threshold, along with other relevant criteria deemed important by the Regulator [#TGT:223a987c-f08a-4402-8d01-2472978dd1e8]. The FSRA will then notify the Authorised Person of its decision [#SRC:ee620070-0c48-454c-9530-0b3abf34c142].

debug_context.source_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS FOR AUTHORISED PERSONS ENGAGED IN REGULATED ACTIVITIES IN RELATION TO VIRTUAL ASSETS Accepted Virtual Assets An Authorised Person wishing to use a Virtual Asset(s) additional to the Accepted Virtual Asset(s) originally approved as part of its application process, must first seek the FSRAs approval before offering it to Clients. This application should be made in writing and include all relevant information relating to the use of the Virtual Asset, including the relevant controls the Authorised Person has in place (or if not already in place, that it proposes to implement), in order to manage any risks specific to the Virtual Asset. In forming a view on the suitability of the proposed Virtual Asset(s), the FSRA will take into account whether the proposed Virtual Asset meets the requirements to be an Accepted Virtual Asset, as set out in COBS Rule 17.2.2 and paragraph 25 of this Guidance. The FSRA will notify the Authorised Person of its determination.
debug_context.target_text: For the purposes of determining whether, in its opinion, a Virtual Asset meets the requirements of being an Accepted Virtual Asset, the Regulator will consider – (a) a maturity/market capitalisation threshold in respect of a Virtual Asset; and (b) other factors that, in the opinion of the Regulator, are to be taken into account in determining whether or not a Virtual Asset meets the requirements to be considered appropriate for the purpose of an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets.

question: Under what circumstances must an Appointed auditor communicate information or opinions to the Regulator, and how do these requirements relate to the obligations of Authorised Persons and Recognised Bodies under the FSMR?
expected_answer: An Appointed auditor is required to communicate information or opinions to the Regulator if they reasonably believe there has been or may have been a contravention of any requirement imposed by the Regulations, which may be of material significance to the Regulator's decision-making regarding its powers [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6]. This obligation aligns with the broader requirement for Authorised Persons and Recognised Bodies to disclose any matter indicating a breach or likely breach of Regulations or Rules to the Regulator, as stipulated under Part 16 and section 193 of the FSMR [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b]. Both sets of requirements emphasize the importance of transparency and compliance in regulatory matters.

debug_context.source_text: Each Authorised Person, Recognised Body and its Auditors is also required under Part 16 and section 193 of the FSMR respectively, to disclose to the Regulator any matter which may indicate a breach or likely breach of, or a failure or likely failure to comply with, Regulations or Rules. Each Authorised Person and Recognised Body is also required to establish and implement systems and procedures to enable its compliance and compliance by its Auditors with notification requirements.
debug_context.target_text: Reports to the Regulator An Appointed auditor must communicate to the Regulator information on, or his opinion on, matters mentioned in sections ‎191‎(3) and ‎192‎(3) in the following circumstances— (a) the auditor reasonably believes that, as regards the person concerned— (i) there is or has been, or may be or may have been, a contravention of any requirement imposed by or under these Regulations that applies to the person concerned; and (ii) that contravention may be of material significance to the Regulator in determining whether to exercise, in relation to the person concerned, any of its powers; (b) the auditor reasonably believes that the information on, or his opinion on, those matters may be of material significance to the Regulator in determining whether the person concerned satisfies and will continue to satisfy the Threshold Conditions or, in the case of a Recognised Body, the Recognition Requirements applicable to that person; (c) the auditor reasonably believes that the person concerned is not, may not be, or may cease to be, a going concern; (d) the auditor is precluded from stating in his report that the annual accounts or, where they are required to be made by any of the following provisions, other financial reports of the person concerned— (i) have been properly prepared in accordance with the Companies Regulations or, where applicable, give a true and fair view of the matters referred to in section 467(3)(a) (Auditor's report on Company's annual accounts) of those Regulations; (ii) have been prepared so as to conform with the requirements of Rules made under these Regulations where the auditor is, by Rules made under section ‎189, required to make such a statement; or (iii) where applicable, the auditor is required to state in his report in relation to the person concerned any of the facts referred to in subsection (2), (3) or (5) of section 469 (Duties of auditor) of the Companies Regulations.

question: What are the requirements for a Reporting Entity regarding the appointment of an auditor under section 82 of the FSMR, and how must this appointment align with Part 15 and related Rules?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity is obligated to appoint an auditor as mandated by section 82 of the FSMR [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33]. This appointment must be conducted in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules established for the purposes of that Part [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]. The alignment with Part 15 ensures that the appointment process adheres to the specific regulatory framework and standards set forth for financial reporting and auditing. question: Under what circumstances is a person required to attend an interview and answer questions, and what are the limitations on refusing to answer based on self-incrimination or confidentiality?
expected_answer: A person required to attend an interview must first receive written notice mandating their attendance to answer questions [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda]. They are not entitled to refuse or fail to answer questions on the grounds that their answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty, or might reveal a confidential communication, subject to section 209(6) of FSMR [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda]. Additionally, it is not a reasonable excuse to refuse or fail to answer questions, permit inspection and copying of documents, or produce information under sections 201, 203, and 206(1)(a), (b), (c), and (e) on the basis that the information might incriminate the person or reveal a confidential communication, subject to section 209(6) [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab].

debug_context.source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . A person required to attend an interview will first be provided with written notice requiring their attendance at the interview to answer questions. Pursuant to section 206(5) of FSMR, an interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question on the basis that their answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section 209(6) of FSMR).
debug_context.target_text: Subject to section ‎210‎(3), it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to— (a) permit inspection and copying of any information or Document; (b) give or produce, or procure the giving or production of, any information or Document; or (c) answer questions; pursuant to any requirement under sections ‎201, ‎203 and ‎206‎(1)‎(a), ‎(b), ‎(c) and ‎(e) on the grounds that any such information or Document or answer, as the case may be— (d) might tend to incriminate the person; or (e) is, or contains, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section ‎209‎(6)).

question: Under what conditions must the Regulator consult the Recognised Body before issuing a direction under Rule 6.5.4 or Rule 6.5.6, and what are the necessary considerations for the Regulator to be satisfied with the direction?
expected_answer: The Regulator is required to consult the Recognised Body before issuing a direction under both Rule 6.5.4 and Rule 6.5.6. For Rule 6.5.4, the Regulator must be satisfied that failure to act would pose undue risk to investors or market participants, that the direction is necessary for public interest in financial stability, or that it facilitates a proposed or possible use of power under chapter 16 of COBS or Rule 6.5.7(c) [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a]. For Rule 6.5.6, the Regulator must determine that taking action would be premature or undesirable for investors or market participants, that the direction is necessary for public interest in financial stability, or that it facilitates a proposed or possible use of power under chapter 16 of COBS or a particular exercise of power under that Part [#TGT:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3].

debug_context.source_text: Before giving such a direction under Rule 6.5.4, the Regulator shall consult the Recognised Body in question, and the Regulator shall not give a direction unless the Regulator is satisfied, in the light of that consultation that: (a) failure to take action would involve undue risk to investors or other participants in the market; (b) the direction is necessary having regard to the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (c) the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that chapter, or Rule 6.5.7(c).
debug_context.target_text: Before giving a direction under Rule 6.5.6, the Regulator shall consult the Recognised Body in question, and the Regulator shall not give a direction unless the Regulator is satisfied, in the light of that consultation that: (a) the taking of action would be premature or otherwise undesirable in the interests of investors or other participants in the market; (b) the direction is necessary having regard to the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (c) the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that Part.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator issue a Direction Notice to a Reporting Entity to disclose specified information, and what additional powers does the Regulator have in the interests of the Abu Dhabi Global Market?
expected_answer: The Regulator may issue a Direction Notice to a Reporting Entity to disclose specified information if the Reporting Entity fails to comply with its disclosure obligations under the FSMR and related Rules, or to correct or prevent a false market in a Listed Entity's Securities [#SRC:f416d7fa-af65-48d6-a16f-ed11a6daadac]. Additionally, the Regulator has the power to direct a Reporting Entity to disclose information or take other appropriate steps if it is satisfied that such actions are in the interests of the Abu Dhabi Global Market [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94]. The Regulator may also impose additional continuing obligations on the Reporting Entity under terms and conditions it determines [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94].

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator may, pursuant to its power under section 84 of the FSMR, issue a written notice directing a Reporting Entity (a "Direction Notice") to disclose specified information and to take any other steps as the Regulator considers appropriate in the following circumstances: (a) where a Reporting Entity fails to comply with an obligation to Disclose any information under the FSMR and these Rules; (b) to correct or prevent a false market if the Regulator considers that there is or is likely to be a false market in a Listed Entity's Securities;
debug_context.target_text: Miscellaneous . Regulator's powers of Direction The Regulator may, if it is satisfied that it is in the interests of the Abu Dhabi Global Market to do so— (a) direct a Reporting Entity to disclose specified information to the market or take such other steps as the Regulator considers appropriate; or (b) impose on a Reporting Entity any additional continuing obligations; on such terms and conditions as determined by the Regulator.

question: How must an Authorised Person adjust the deduction of defined benefit pension fund assets from CET1 Capital, considering the potential for deferred tax liabilities and the unrestricted use of certain assets?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets from its CET1 Capital calculation, as specified in the relevant rules [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. However, this deduction can be reduced by the amount of any associated deferred tax liability that could be extinguished if the assets were impaired or derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada]. Additionally, the deduction can be further reduced by the amount of assets in the pension fund that the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use, provided that adequate advance notification of the intention to use those assets has been given to the Regulator [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada]. These assets must then receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of the Rules [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada].

debug_context.source_text: CET1 Deductions - defined benefit pension fund assets. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(d), the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted from CET1 Capital must be reduced by the following: (a) the amount of any associated deferred tax liability which could be extinguished if the assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and (b) the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund which the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use where the Authorised Person has provided adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets to the Regulator. Those assets used to reduce the amount to be deducted must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules.
debug_context.target_text: CET1 Deductions. Subject to the following Rules in this Section, an Authorised Person must deduct the following from the calculation of its CET1 Capital: (a) losses for the current financial year; (b) goodwill and other intangible assets as defined in the International Financial Reporting Standards; (c) deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability; (d) defined benefit pension fund assets of the Authorised Person; (e) the applicable amount, by reference to Rule 3.10.12, of direct and indirect holdings by an Authorised Person of its own CET1 Capital instruments including instruments under which an Authorised Person is under an actual or contingent obligation to effect a purchase by virtue of an existing contractual obligation; (f) holdings of the CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where those entities have a reciprocal cross holding with the Authorised Person which have the effect of artificially inflating the Capital Resources of the Authorised Person; (g) the applicable amount, by reference to Rule 3.10.13, of direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person does not have a significant investment in those entities; (h) the applicable amount, by reference to Rules 3.10.13 and 3.10.18, of direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of the CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person has a significant investment in those entities; (i) the amount of items required to be deducted from the calculation of AT1 Capital in accordance with the relevant Rules under Section 3.11, that exceeds the AT1 Capital of the Authorised Person; (j) the Exposure amount of the following items which qualify for a risk weight of 1000%, where the Authorised Person deducts that Exposure amount from CET1 Capital as an alternative to applying a risk weight of 1000%: (i) Qualifying Holdings; (ii) securitisation positions, in accordance with relevant Rules in Chapter 4; and (iii) free deliveries, in accordance with the Rules in Section A4.6; and (k) for an Authorised Person which is a Partnership, the amount by which the aggregate of the amounts withdrawn by its Partners or members exceeds the profits of that firm.

question: What should an Authorised Person's Governing Body do to check if their Capital Resources are enough, and what extra steps must a Domestic Firm take to make sure it can pay its bills on time?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person's Governing Body needs to check if the Capital Resources required by the Regulator are enough for its business model and risk profile [#SRC:097ade5d-12c3-4d41-876b-1634652a822d]. If they find these resources are not enough, they should keep extra resources [#SRC:097ade5d-12c3-4d41-876b-1634652a822d]. A Domestic Firm must always have the Capital Resources specified in the Rules [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56]. It also needs to keep extra capital and liquid assets that fit its business's nature, size, and complexity to avoid any big risk of not being able to pay its bills on time [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56].

debug_context.source_text: For the purposes of Rule 3.2.4, an Authorised Person's Governing Body should assess whether the Capital Resources which are required by the Regulator as set out in these Rules are adequate in relation to the Authorised Person's specific business model and risk profile. Additional resources should be maintained by the Authorised Person where its Governing Body has considered that the required Capital Resources do not adequately reflect the nature and risks of the Authorised Person's business.
debug_context.target_text: Domestic Firms – maintaining capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must: (a) have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules; (b) ensure that it maintains capital and liquid assets in addition to the requirement in (a) which are adequate in relation to the nature, size and complexity of its business to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate the Total Risk Exposure Amount, and what specific multiplication factor is applied to certain capital requirements?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is required to calculate the Total Risk Exposure Amount by summing several specific Risk Exposure Amounts. These include the Credit RWA, Market Risk Capital Requirement, Operational Risk Capital Requirement, CVA Risk Capital Requirement, and, where applicable, the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement [#SRC:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. To determine the Risk Exposure Amounts associated with the Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirements, the Authorised Person must multiply the individual capital requirements by a factor of 12.5 [#TGT:c6eab1e6-6274-4d4d-b4b7-22ad0f9fe1c1].

debug_context.source_text: Total Risk Exposure Amount. An Authorised Person must calculate its Total Risk Exposure Amount, after taking into account the provisions of Rule 3.5.8, as the sum of: (a) the Credit RWA as calculated using Rule 4.8.1(2); (b) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with the Market Risk Capital Requirement; (c) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with the Operational Risk Capital Requirement; (d) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with the CVA Risk Capital Requirement; and (e) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement, where applicable, calculated in accordance with IFR Rule 5.4.5.
debug_context.target_text: Total Risk Exposure Amount. An Authorised Person must multiply the individual capital requirements referred to under points 3.5.7(b) to 3.5.7(e) by a factor of 12.5 in order to determine the Risk Exposure Amounts associated with those elements of the Total Risk Exposure Amount.

question: What are the obligations of an Authorised Person before establishing a business relationship with a Retail Client concerning OTC Leveraged Products, and how do these obligations relate to assessing the Retail Client's understanding of risks and potential losses?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must ensure that before establishing a business relationship with a Retail Client concerning OTC Leveraged Products, they conduct a thorough assessment of the Retail Client's skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources, and risk tolerance [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0]. This assessment is crucial to determine if the Retail Client has adequate experience and skill to understand the potential risks of loss involved in such investments and possesses liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0]. Additionally, prior to establishing any business relationship, the Authorised Person should consider whether the Retail Client demonstrates an understanding of the risks and potential magnitude of losses they may be exposed to [#SRC:e79e3adf-b4c6-4c32-81c3-6440c56574a6]. These obligations ensure that the Retail Client is adequately informed and prepared for the financial implications of trading in OTC Leveraged Products.

debug_context.source_text: In order to satisfy the requirements imposed by Rule 23.5.1, the Authorised Person should, prior to establishing a business relationship with a Retail Client, consider whether such Retail Client demonstrates an understanding of the risks and potential magnitude of losses which they may be exposed to.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person must not offer OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, or provide any advice or make arrangements on behalf of a Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products unless it has first completed an assessment of the skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance of the Retail Client, such that the Authorised Person may reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has: (a) adequate experience and skill enabling them to understand the potential risk of loss involved in investing in OTC Leveraged Products; and (b) liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses resulting from trading in OTC Leveraged Products.

question: When an Authorised Person is calculating E* for pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, what methods must be used to determine the appropriate haircuts, and how does this relate to the calculation of the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate E* for pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs that are covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement by applying either standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8]. This calculation is necessary when the Authorised Person is using the FCCA and has taken eligible financial Collateral for the SFT [#SRC:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776]. The calculated E* must then be substituted for E when determining the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty, in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 [#SRC:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776].

debug_context.source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty covered by the qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 (if the Authorised Person is using supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts), and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8.
debug_context.target_text: Calculation of E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions. An Authorised Person must calculate the appropriate haircuts to be applied using one of the following methods: (a) standard supervisory haircuts; or (b) own estimate haircuts.

question: When an Authorised Person seeks to amend a Financial Services Permission to conduct Islamic Financial Business, what are the fee requirements, and how do these requirements interact with the fees for undertaking additional Regulated Activities?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to conduct Islamic Financial Business must pay an application fee of $5,000 to the Regulator [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. If the amendment also involves undertaking additional Regulated Activities, the Authorised Person must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with those activities at that time [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. Each additional Regulated Activity incurs an additional fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the fee specified in the Rules [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2].

debug_context.source_text: Amendment of a Financial Services Permission other than the addition of a Regulated Activity (a) Subject to Rule 2.1(c), an Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake additional Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator such application fees as set out in Rule 3.2.1. (b) An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to serve Retail Clients, other than pursuant to Rule 3.20.1, must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000. (c) An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to conduct Islamic Financial Business must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000. (d) An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission through the amendment or removal of a condition, other than in accordance with (b) or (c), must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
debug_context.target_text: In respect of: (a) an Applicant seeking to obtain a Financial Service Permission enabling the Applicant to undertake multiple Regulated Activities; or (b) an Authorised Person seeking to amend a Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake one or more additional Regulated Activities. the Applicant or Authorised Person, as the case may be, must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with the Regulated Activities being applied for at that time. Each additional Regulated Activity applied for at that time shall incur an additional application fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the application fee specified in these Rules.

question: Under what conditions does a Prospectus become an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2)(a) of the FSMR, and how does the approval process relate to the requirements prescribed in the Rules?
expected_answer: A Prospectus becomes an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2)(a) of the FSMR only when the Regulator issues a notice to the Applicant stating its approval of the Prospectus or Supplementary Prospectus, including all documents if it comprises multiple documents [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. This approval must be in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, as a Prospectus is considered an Approved Prospectus if it meets these regulatory standards [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1].

debug_context.source_text: A Prospectus filed with the Regulator is not an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2)(a) of the FSMR unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval: (a) of the Prospectus or the Supplementary Prospectus as the case may be; and (b) in the case of a Prospectus in (a) comprising multiple documents, of all the multiple documents.
debug_context.target_text: For the purposes of subsection ‎(1)— (a) a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules; and (b) a reference to a Prospectus made by or under these Regulations is a reference to an Approved Prospectus, unless the context requires otherwise.

question: When can someone share Confidential Information if they got it from a primary recipient, and what consents are needed?
expected_answer: Confidential Information can be shared by someone who got it from a primary recipient only if they have prior consent from both the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information and, if different, the person to whom it relates. This ensures that the duty of confidentiality is respected, as required by both the SOURCE and TARGET texts. The SOURCE specifies that the Regulator and its agents need similar consents to disclose such information [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a], while the TARGET emphasizes the need for consent from the person to whom the information relates [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866].

debug_context.source_text: With prior consent under section 198(1) of FSMR. Section 198(1) prohibits disclosure of Confidential Information by the Regulator, its employees, agents or by any person coming into possession of Confidential Information unless they have the prior consent of (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained; and, (b) if different, the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed (paragraphs 198(1)(a) and (b)).
debug_context.target_text: Confidential Information must not be disclosed by a primary recipient, or by any person obtaining the information directly or indirectly from a primary recipient, without the prior consent of— (a) the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information; and (b) if different, the person to whom it relates.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator refrain from transmitting a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) despite the requirement to provide notice of intent to use passporting procedures within five Business Days?
expected_answer: The Regulator may refrain from transmitting a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it determines that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation, or if it has reasonable grounds to believe that they may not comply in the future [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. Additionally, the Regulator may also choose not to transmit the notice if it considers it necessary and appropriate to further one or more of its objectives [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. This decision must be made within the context of the requirement to provide notice of intent to use passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days of receiving the notice set out in Rule 3.1.2, as stipulated in the TARGET passage [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7].

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator shall not transmit a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a): (a) if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with, or it has reasonable grounds for determining that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund may in the future not comply with, applicable legislation including these Rules; or (b) if it considers that it is necessary and appropriate to refrain from doing so in order to further one or more of its objectives.
debug_context.target_text: The Regulator shall: (a) Within five Business Days of receipt of the notice set out in Rule 3.1.2, and subject to Rule 3.1.5, provide notice of the intent to use the passporting procedures under these Rules to the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted; and (b) promptly following confirmation from the relevant Host Regulator(s) that its respective Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the details of the Passported Fund: (i) publish the details of the Passported Fund on the Register of Passported Funds; and (ii) notify the Fund Manager that registration on the Register of Passported Funds is complete.

question: How must an Authorised Person manage the exclusion of T2 Capital when calculating capital resources for firms authorised to manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account, specifically a PSIAu, under the relevant rules?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account, specifically a PSIAu, must exclude from T2 Capital any amount by which the combined total of the Profit Equalisation Reserve and the Investment Risk Reserve exceeds the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement, as calculated according to the IFR rules [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2]. This exclusion is prescribed within Part 4 of the capital resources calculation framework, specifically under Rule 3.12.9, which provides an exemption for firms authorised to manage such accounts [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4].

debug_context.source_text: In particular, note that: a. Part 3 (Calculating Capital Requirements) applies to all firms, but with differentiated calculations for the Capital Requirement for the various Categories of Authorised Persons, as prescribed in Sections 3.4 and 3.6; b. Part 4 (Calculating Capital Resources) applies to all firms; and c. within Part 4, an exemption from the calculation of T2 Capital in relation to firms authorised to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu is prescribed in Rule 3.12.9.
debug_context.target_text: T2 Exclusion - Managing an unrestricted Profit Sharing Investment Account. An Authorised Person must exclude from T2 Capital any amount by which the total of the Profit Equalisation Reserve and the Investment Risk Reserve exceeds the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with the IFR rules.

question: What are the capital holding requirements for an Authorised Person when a Clean Up Call is not met in a Traditional Securitisation, and how does this relate to the conditions under which a Clean Up Call may be exercised?
expected_answer: When the conditions for a Clean Up Call are not met in a Traditional Securitisation, the Authorised Person must hold capital against the Exposures as if they had not been securitised [#SRC:8b60fc75-9ebd-44e6-ad28-75569bd164ab]. This requirement is linked to the operational conditions for Clean Up Calls, which stipulate that the exercise of a Clean Up Call must not be mandatory and must not be structured to avoid losses or provide Credit Enhancement [#TGT:c441b5bc-c812-4c03-aef7-a0914da00b87].

debug_context.source_text: Operational requirements for the treatment of Clean Up Calls. Where the conditions listed in Rule A4.10.3 are not met the Authorised Person must hold capital against the Exposures as follows: (a) for a Traditional Securitisation the underlying Exposures must be treated as if they had not been securitised; (b) Authorised Persons must not include any gain on sale in any element or component of their Capital Resources; (c) for Synthetic Securitisations, the Authorised Person must hold capital against the entire amount of securitised Exposures; and (d) where a Synthetic Securitisation incorporates a call that is not a Clean Up Call, the Authorised Person must treat the transaction in accordance with the relevant CRM techniques in Section 4.13.
debug_context.target_text: Operational requirements for the treatment of Clean Up Calls. Where a Clean Up Call is included within a securitisation, the Authorised Person which has the ability to exercise the Clean Up Call must ensure that: (a) the exercise of the Clean Up Call must not be mandatory, in form or substance; (b) the Clean Up Call must not be structured to avoid allocating losses to Credit Enhancements, or positions held by investors or in any way structured to provide Credit Enhancement; and (c) the Clean Up Call must only be exercisable when 10% or less of the original underlying Exposures or Securities issued in that securitisation remains, or in the case of a Synthetic Securitisation, when 10% or less of the original reference portfolio value remains.

question: When can a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree not to follow some rules, and what must the Provider prove if a transaction is disputed?
expected_answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person can agree with a Third Party Provider in writing to not follow certain rules, like those about charges or consent withdrawal [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. If a transaction is disputed, the Third Party Provider must prove it was properly authorized, recorded, and processed, and that there were no technical issues or service problems [#TGT:b0cfd1ae-ec85-4eb8-bc00-8e500e740a92].

debug_context.source_text: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that the following Rules do not apply: (a) Rules 20.2.15 and 20.2.16 (charges for information); (b) Rule 20.7.3 and 20.7.4 (withdrawal of consent); (c) Rule 20.8.2 (revocation of a Payment Order); (d) Rules 20.10.1 and 20.10.2 (requests for refund); (e) Rule 20.11.1 (evidence on authentication and execution); (f) Rule 20.12.5 (liability for charges); and the parties may agree that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1.
debug_context.target_text: Where a Customer: (a) denies having authorised an executed Third Party Transaction; or (b) claims that a Third Party Transaction has not been correctly executed; it is for the Third Party Provider to prove that the Third Party Transaction was authenticated, accurately recorded, processed in line with the Third Party Provider’s procedures for executing Third Party Transactions and not affected by a technical breakdown or some other deficiency in the service provided by the Third Party Provider or any third party it relies upon for the performance of operational functions.

question: What are the obligations of a Recognised Investment Exchange when determining if a participant or Member has exceeded a position limit for a Derivative, and how must these obligations be executed in accordance with Rule 3.3.9?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange is required to have the capabilities to ascertain whether a participant or Member has exceeded any position limit set for a Derivative or class of Derivatives, as mandated by Rule 3.3.9 [#SRC:eadea557-36b4-4076-8a57-1d53f951f4a8]. In executing this obligation, the Exchange must consider positions held by any other Person directly or indirectly controlled by the participant or Member, as well as positions held by any other Person acting under an agreement or understanding as if the position were held by the participant or Member [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17]. Additionally, positions held in respect of an Option on the Derivative contract must be calculated on a Derivative equivalent basis [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17]. This comprehensive approach ensures compliance with the position limits set forth.

debug_context.source_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange must have the capabilities to determine whether a participant or Member has exceeded any position limit set in respect of any Derivative or class of Derivatives in accordance with Rule 3.3.9.
debug_context.target_text: When determining whether a position limit imposed in respect of a Derivative has been exceeded by a participant or Member trading in the Derivative, a Recognised Investment Exchange must take into account: (a) any position held by any other Person directly, or indirectly, controlled by the participant or Member; (b) any position held by any other Person acting, pursuant to an express or implied agreement or understanding, as if such position were held by the participant or Member; and (c) any position held in respect of an Option on the Derivative contract, calculated on a Derivative equivalent basis.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator withdraw an Approval under section 45, and what factors will be considered in determining the fitness and propriety of an Approved Person?
expected_answer: The Regulator may withdraw an Approval given under section 45 if it determines that the person is not fit and proper to perform the Controlled Function in question [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554]. In making this determination, the Regulator will consider various factors, including the criteria for assessing fitness and propriety as outlined in GEN 5.2.9 and section 2.3 of GPM [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c]. Additional considerations include any offences or findings of dishonesty, fraud, or financial crime by the Approved Person, whether other enforcement actions have been taken, the specific Controlled Function performed, the nature and activities of the firm, the markets in which the firm operates, and the severity of the risk posed to consumers and confidence in the ADGM financial system [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c].

debug_context.source_text: In determining whether to exercise our power under section 46 of FSMR, we will have regard to all relevant matters including, but not limited to: (a) the criteria for assessing the fitness and propriety of an Approved Person as set out in GEN 5.2.9 and section 2.3 of GPM; (b) the commission of any offences or a finding involving dishonesty, fraud or a financial crime by the Approved Person; (c) whether other enforcement action should be taken, or has already been taken, against the Approved Person by us or by other enforcement agencies; (d) the particular Controlled Function the Approved Person is or was performing; (e) the nature and activities of the firm concerned; (f) the markets in which the firm operates; and (g) the severity of the risk that the individual poses to consumers and to confidence in the ADGM financial system.
debug_context.target_text: Withdrawal of Controlled Function Approval The Regulator may withdraw an Approval given under section ‎45 if the Regulator considers that the person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question.

question: Under what conditions is an Authorised Person exempt from calculating the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement for exposure to foreign currencies and gold under an Islamic Contract?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is exempt from calculating the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement if specific conditions are met. Firstly, the Authorised Person's Foreign Currency business, which is the greater of the sum of its gross long positions and the sum of its gross short positions in all Foreign Currencies, must not exceed 100% of its Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3 [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97]. Additionally, the overall net open position, as defined in Rule A6.4.4, must not exceed 2% of its Capital Resources [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97]. These conditions provide an exemption from the requirement to calculate the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement, which is otherwise mandatory for exposure to foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696].

debug_context.source_text: Market risk. An Authorised Person which is exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract, must calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with PRU Rule 5.6.2.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person need not calculate a Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement if: (a) its Foreign Currency business, defined as the greater of the sum of its gross long positions and the sum of its gross short positions in all Foreign Currencies, does not exceed 100% of Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3; and (b) its overall net open position as defined in Rule A6.4.4 does not exceed 2% of its Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3.

question: During a period of financial stress, what obligations does an Authorised Person have regarding the liquidation of HQLA and notification to the Regulator if the LCR Requirement is not met?
expected_answer: During a period of financial stress, an Authorised Person is permitted to liquidate part of its stock of High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA) to cover cash outflows, even if this results in the HQLA level falling below the required Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) Requirement [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f]. However, if the Authorised Person does not meet its LCR Requirement or becomes aware of circumstances that may lead to non-compliance, it must immediately notify the Regulator in writing [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c]. This notification obligation applies even during the stress period when the liquidation of HQLA is taking place [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c].

debug_context.source_text: Liquidation of assets during periods of stress . During a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person may liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows. Subject to Rule 9.3.9, the Authorised Person's level of HQLA may fall below the levels required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with cash outflows during that period.
debug_context.target_text: Notification if LCR Requirement is not met . An Authorised Person must notify the Regulator in writing immediately if it does not meet, or becomes aware of circumstances that may result in it not meeting, at any time, its LCR Requirement (including during a period of stress referred to in Rule 9.3.8).

question: When the Default Rules make provisions for Designated Non-Members similar to those for Members of the Recognised Clearing House, what procedures must the Recognised Clearing House have in place according to Rule 4.5.8?
expected_answer: When the Default Rules extend similar provisions to Designated Non-Members as they do to Members of the Recognised Clearing House, the Recognised Clearing House is required to implement adequate procedures. These procedures must include designating the Persons or descriptions of persons for whom actions may be taken [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d]. Additionally, the Recognised Clearing House must regularly review which Persons or descriptions of persons should continue to be designated or have their designation withdrawn [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d]. This requirement is contingent upon the Designated Non-Members being designated in accordance with the procedures mentioned in Rule 4.5.9 [#SRC:817f6968-e9c3-4cb9-89c7-cf942d033bb4].

debug_context.source_text: The Default Rules may make the same or similar provision, in relation to Designated Non-Members that have been designated as such in accordance with the procedures mentioned in Rule 4.5.9, as in relation to Members of the Recognised Clearing House.
debug_context.target_text: If such provision is made as allowed under Rule 4.5.8, the Recognised Clearing House must have adequate procedures for: (a) designating the Persons, or descriptions of person, in respect of whom action may be taken; (b) keeping under review the question which Persons or descriptions of person should be or remain so designated; and (c) withdrawing such designation.

question: What happens if a Recognised Body files late and doesn't pay the fee on time?
expected_answer: If a Recognised Body submits a Regulatory Filing late, it must pay a $500 fee to the Regulator [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105]. If the fee is not paid by the due date, a late payment fee applies, which is either $2,000 or 3% of the fee due, whichever is higher [#SRC:cc25dcfa-a71c-4784-b694-9e305d7dee51]. Additionally, the fee increases by 1% for each month or part of a month it remains unpaid [#SRC:cc25dcfa-a71c-4784-b694-9e305d7dee51].

debug_context.source_text: Late payment Except for late Regulatory Filings for which a fee is incurred in accordance with Rule 1.2.7, when a fee is not paid in full on or before the due date or within the prescribed period, such non-payment incurs a late payment fee of: (a) $2,000; or (b) an amount equivalent to 3% of the fee due, whichever is the greater. In addition, the outstanding fee due shall be increased by 1% for each calendar month, or part of a calendar month, that it remains outstanding beyond the due date.
debug_context.target_text: Late Payment Fees relating to Regulatory Filings An Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession or a Recognised Body that submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date must pay to the Regulator a fee of $500.

question: When can the Regulator tell a Fund Manager to change the name of a Fund or Sub-Fund, and what reasons must there be for this to happen?
expected_answer: The Regulator can instruct a Fund Manager to change the name of a Fund or Sub-Fund if it believes the name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with another Fund or Sub-Fund's name [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff]. question: What are the notification requirements for a Person referred to in Rule 3.7.2 when a notifiable interest in a Listed Fund arises or changes, and how is a notifiable interest defined?
expected_answer: A Person referred to in Rule 3.7.2 must notify the other members of the Governing Body within five Business Days when a notifiable interest arises or changes [#SRC:6786cba0-c996-4e15-b9a7-84ae5417cab9]. A notifiable interest is defined as any interest a member of the Governing Body of a Listed Fund has through direct or indirect ownership, beneficial ownership of Units, or any financial or commercial arrangement related to the Listed Fund [#TGT:f46130c3-20bf-4c61-b32d-f638950b9c65].

debug_context.source_text: A notice relating to a notifiable interest must, subject only to (2), be given by a Person referred to in Rule 3.7.2 to the other members of the Governing Body within five Business Days of the notifiable interest arising or changing.
debug_context.target_text: Definition of a notifiable interest. A member of the Governing Body of a Listed Fund has a notifiable interest in the Listed Fund if that Person has any interest arising through: (1) the direct or indirect ownership of, or beneficial ownership of, Units of the Listed Fund; or (2) any involvement in financial or commercial arrangement with or relating to the Listed Fund.

question: Under what conditions would an Authorised Person be classified as Category 3B rather than Category 2, considering their Financial Services Permission and the scope of their dealing activities?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is classified as Category 3B if its Financial Services Permission authorises it to provide custody for a Fund or act as a Trustee of an Investment Trust, and it does not meet the criteria for Categories 1, 2, 3A, or 5 [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe]. In contrast, to be classified as Category 2, the Authorised Person must be authorised to provide credit or deal in investments as Principal, with no limitations on the scope of its dealing activities as per Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i), and must not meet the criteria for Categories 1 or 5 [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. Therefore, the classification hinges on the specific regulated activities authorised and the absence of authorisation for certain activities specified in the rules.

debug_context.source_text: Category 3B An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if: (a) its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of: (i) Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or (ii) Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and (b) it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5. Guidance A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if: (a) its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal); (b) its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and (c) it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5. Category 3A Guidance A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.

question: What are the specific conditions an Authorised Person must satisfy to classify a Person as a Market Counterparty, considering both the qualification as a deemed Professional Client and the notification requirements?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may classify a Person as a Market Counterparty if the Person qualifies as a deemed Professional Client in accordance with Rule 2.4.2 and the requirements in Rule 2.5(b) have been met [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413]. Additionally, before finalizing this classification, the Authorised Person must ensure that the Person has received prior written notification of the classification as a Market Counterparty, either in relation to a specific Regulated Activity or Transaction, or for all such activities and transactions [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. The Person must also not have requested to be classified otherwise within the period specified in the notice [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3].

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate E* for pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs when eligible financial Collateral is taken and the transaction is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate E* for pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs by applying the FCCA when eligible financial Collateral is taken and the transaction is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de]. The calculation of E* involves determining the appropriate haircuts, which can be done using either standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8]. Once E* is calculated, it must be substituted for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount under Section 4.8 [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de].

debug_context.source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.
debug_context.target_text: Calculation of E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions. An Authorised Person must calculate the appropriate haircuts to be applied using one of the following methods: (a) standard supervisory haircuts; or (b) own estimate haircuts.

question: What must a Public Listed Company do to meet the rules for appointing an auditor and having its financial statements audited?
expected_answer: A Public Listed Company must appoint an auditor as required by section 82 of the FSMR [#SRC:ad712be8-a953-4486-a76d-484a73126c91]. The auditor needs to audit the company's financial statements following the standards set by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB) or other standards that the Regulator accepts [#SRC:ad712be8-a953-4486-a76d-484a73126c91]. Additionally, as a Reporting Entity, the company must appoint an auditor according to Part 15 and any related Rules [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]. This ensures compliance with both the FSMR and the specific rules for Reporting Entities.

question: Under what circumstances must a Payment Service Provider refund an unauthorised Payment Transaction and restore the Payment Account, considering the failure to provide information as per Section 19.5?
expected_answer: A Payment Service Provider is obligated to refund an unauthorised Payment Transaction and restore the Payment Account to its original state if the transaction was not authorised according to Rule 19.10.1 [#SRC:49dd4b51-276a-406c-ab4c-17a9797a7a7a]. This obligation persists even if the Payment Service User did not notify the Payment Service Provider within the time period specified in Rule 19.17.1, provided the Payment Service Provider failed to supply or make available the necessary information about the Payment Transaction as required by Section 19.5 [#TGT:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4].

debug_context.target_text: Where the Payment Service Provider has failed to provide or make available information concerning the Payment Transaction in accordance with Section 19.5, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress under the Rules in this Chapter notwithstanding that the Payment Service User has failed to notify the Payment Service Provider within the time period stated in Rule 19.17.1.

question: How does an Authorised Person figure out the Credit RWA for its Credit Risk Exposures, and what steps do they need to take?
expected_answer: To determine the Credit RWA, an Authorised Person adds up the risk-weighted assets for all its Credit Risk Exposures, along with Securitisation and Counterparty Risk Exposures [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]. For Credit Risk Exposures, the steps are: (a) calculate each Exposure's value using the method in Section 4.9 and consider any Credit Risk Mitigation [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]; (b) categorise the Exposure as per Section 4.10; (c) assign a Credit Quality Grade and risk weight according to Sections 4.11 and 4.12; (d) compute the RWA using the formula RWA(CR) = E x CRW, where 'E' is the Exposure value and 'CRW' is the risk weight [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]; and (e) sum up the RWA amounts for all CR Exposures [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]. This ensures all exposures are properly included in the Credit RWA.

debug_context.source_text: The Credit RWA of an Authorised Person is the sum of: (a) its risk weighted assets (RWA) for all its Credit Risk Exposures (referred to in these Rules as "CR Exposures") calculated in accordance with Rules 4.8.2 and 4.8.3; (b) its RWA for all its securitisation Exposures (referred to in these Rules as "SE Exposures") calculated in accordance with Rule 4.8.4 and Section 4.14; and (c) its RWA for its Counterparty Risk Exposures as calculated in accordance with Sections A4.6 to A4.8.
debug_context.target_text: Calculation of RWA for Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures). To calculate its RWA for CR Exposures, an Authorised Person must: (a) calculate the value of the Exposure (represented as "E") for every on-balance sheet and every off balance sheet asset in accordance with the Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM; (b) categorise that Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.10; (c) allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade and risk weight for that Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.11 and 4.12; (d) calculate the RWA amount for that Exposure using the following formula: RWA(CR) = E x CRW where: (i) "RWA(CR)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure; (ii) "E" refers to the Exposure value or amount, for that CR Exposure; and (iii) "CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for that CR Exposure determined in accordance with (b) and (c); and (e) add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (d) for all its CR Exposures.

question: What are the obligations of a Listed Entity regarding Restriction Agreements and holding locks during a Restriction Period, and what timing requirements must be met for obtaining an undertaking related to Restricted Securities?
expected_answer: During a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity, Security Holder, or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement is prohibited from amending an executed Restriction Agreement or requesting the release of a holding lock imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d]. Additionally, the Listed Entity must obtain and submit to the Regulator an undertaking from a suitable entity, such as a bank or custodian, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities within two Business Days after their issue. This undertaking must also include a commitment not to release the holding lock without the Regulator's prior written consent [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76].

debug_context.source_text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. During a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity, Security Holder or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement must not: (1) amend an executed Restriction Agreement; or (2) ask for or agree to the release of a holding lock that has been imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9.
debug_context.target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate the RWA for Credit Risk Exposures, considering the measurement methodology and applicable CRM effects?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate the RWA for Credit Risk Exposures by first determining the value of each Exposure, denoted as 'E', for both on-balance sheet and off-balance sheet assets. This calculation must adhere to the Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9, while also taking into account any applicable Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) effects [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]. The methodology for calculating Exposures is prescribed in the relevant Section for determining Credit RWA for Credit Risk Exposures [#SRC:84ee9ffb-686e-47d9-b971-908e8cec77f1]. Subsequently, the Exposure must be categorised according to the Rules in Section 4.10, and an appropriate Credit Quality Grade and risk weight must be allocated in line with Sections 4.11 and 4.12 [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]. The RWA amount is then calculated using the formula RWA(CR) = E x CRW, where CRW is the applicable risk weight determined from the previous steps. Finally, the RWA amounts for all CR Exposures are summed to obtain the total RWA [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368].

debug_context.source_text: The measurement methodology in this Section prescribes the manner of calculation of Exposures for the purpose of determining the Credit RWA for Credit Risk (CR) Exposures as provided in Rule 4.8.3 and for securitisation (SE) Exposures as provided in Rule 4.8.4.
debug_context.target_text: Calculation of RWA for Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures). To calculate its RWA for CR Exposures, an Authorised Person must: (a) calculate the value of the Exposure (represented as "E") for every on-balance sheet and every off balance sheet asset in accordance with the Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM; (b) categorise that Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.10; (c) allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade and risk weight for that Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.11 and 4.12; (d) calculate the RWA amount for that Exposure using the following formula: RWA(CR) = E x CRW where: (i) "RWA(CR)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure; (ii) "E" refers to the Exposure value or amount, for that CR Exposure; and (iii) "CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for that CR Exposure determined in accordance with (b) and (c); and (e) add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (d) for all its CR Exposures.

question: If a Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, when can they and the Payment Service Provider agree to ignore some Rules, and what happens if the Provider doesn't give the right information?
expected_answer: A Payment Service User who is not a Natural Person can agree with the Payment Service Provider in writing to ignore certain Rules, such as those about charges for information and liability for unauthorised transactions [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. However, if the Payment Service Provider fails to give the required information about a Payment Transaction as per Section 19.5, the Payment Service User can still seek redress under the Rules, even if they didn't notify the Provider within the usual time limit [#TGT:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4]. This means the right to redress is maintained regardless of any agreement to ignore some Rules.

debug_context.source_text: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing the following Rules do not apply: (a) Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (charges for information); (b) Rule 19.10.1 (3) and (4) (withdrawal of consent); (c) Rule 19.18.1 (evidence on authentication and execution); (d) Rule 19.20.1 (Payer or Payees liability for unauthorised transactions); (e) Rules 19.17.1 and 19.17.2 (requests for refund); (f) Rule 19.14.3 (revocation of a Payment Order); (g) Rule 19.21.2 (defective execution of Payer-initiated transactions); (h) Rule 19.21.3 (defective execution of Payee-initiated transactions); (i) Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges); and the parties may agree that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1.
debug_context.target_text: Where the Payment Service Provider has failed to provide or make available information concerning the Payment Transaction in accordance with Section 19.5, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress under the Rules in this Chapter notwithstanding that the Payment Service User has failed to notify the Payment Service Provider within the time period stated in Rule 19.17.1.

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure for an SFT when eligible financial Collateral is taken, and what are the implications if the SFT is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must determine the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure for an SFT by considering the latest fair value of Securities lent or sold, or the amount of cash lent or paid, depending on the transaction type, when the SFT is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e]. If eligible financial Collateral is taken, the Authorised Person may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20, which provides a framework for adjusting the exposure measurement [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. This dual consideration ensures that both the presence of Collateral and the absence of a Netting agreement are factored into the exposure calculation.

debug_context.source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
debug_context.target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must determine E, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT which is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement as follows: (a) in the case where the Authorised Person has lent Securities to a Counterparty or sold Securities to a Counterparty with a commitment to repurchase those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold; and (b) in the case where the Authorised Person has lent cash to a Counterparty through the borrowing of Securities from the Counterparty or paid cash for the purchase of Securities from a Counterparty with a commitment to resell those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the amount of cash lent or paid.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator exercise discretion to direct a Captive Insurer, which is not a Cell Company, to establish Long-Term Insurance Funds, and what are the obligations of the Captive Insurer in such a scenario?
expected_answer: The Regulator has the discretion to direct a Captive Insurer, which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business, to establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds, notwithstanding Rule 8.1.1 and 8.1.2 [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7]. If the Captive Insurer is not a Cell Company and carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund under Rule 8.2, it must either establish the required funds or notify the Regulator in writing that it is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469]. This ensures compliance with the Regulator's directive and the provisions of Rule 8.2.

debug_context.source_text: Residual discretion of the Regulator Notwithstanding Rule 8.1.1 and 8.1.2, the Regulator may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds in respect of its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of such business.
debug_context.target_text: Captive Insurer not a Cell Company Where a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that, under the provisions of Rule ‎8.2, must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must either: (a) establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds; or (b) notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator take action against a Fund Manager or its Agent promoting a Passported Fund in ADGM, and what actions may be taken if the activities are materially prejudicial despite measures by the Home Regulator?
expected_answer: The Regulator may take action against a Fund Manager, its Agent, or any other Licensed Person promoting a Passported Fund in ADGM if their activities continue to be materially prejudicial to the Unitholders situated in ADGM or to the financial stability or integrity of ADGM, despite any measures taken by the Home Regulator [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55]. In such cases, the Regulator may prevent further promotion of the Passported Fund, de-register the fund from its Register of Passported Funds, or impose a penalty on the Fund Manager, its Agent, or any other Licensed Person, following consultation with the Home Regulator [#SRC:d4ba7643-bc71-443d-aab5-fac9738f8ae5].

debug_context.source_text: Subject to Rule 9.5.2, the Regulator may take any action that is necessary and appropriate to enable it to further its objectives, including, but not limited to: (a) preventing the Fund Manager, its Agent or any other Licensed Person from further Promotion of the Passported Fund in ADGM, including de-registering the relevant Passported Fund from its Register of Passported Funds; and (b) imposing a penalty on the Fund Manager, its Agent or any other Licensed Person, of such amount as it considers appropriate under applicable ADGM legislation, following consultation with the Home Regulator.
debug_context.target_text: If, despite the measures (if any) taken by a Home Regulator in relation to a Passported Fund, a Fund Manager's activities (or the activities of its Agent or any other Licensed Person that is Promoting the Passported Fund) in ADGM continue to be materially prejudicial to either: (a) the Unitholders of the Passported Fund who are situated in ADGM; or (b) the financial stability or the integrity of ADGM, the Regulator may request urgent discussions with the Home Regulator who has the supervision and enforcement responsibilities in respect of the Passported Fund.
