question: How must a Mining Reporting Entity disclose assumptions related to forecast financial information and Ore Reserves, and what are the requirements if the assumptions are deemed commercially sensitive?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is required to disclose all material economic assumptions used in determining forecast financial information, as well as all other material assumptions employed [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If these assumptions are considered commercially sensitive, the entity must state this and explain the methodology used to determine them [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Additionally, to achieve the necessary level of confidence in the modifying factors for Ore Reserves, the entity must conduct a relevant Technical Study, such as a preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study, and disclose the key assumptions and outcomes of this study [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464]. This ensures transparency and completeness in the disclosure of both forecast financial information and Ore Reserves.

debug_context.source_text: A Mining Reporting Entitys disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
debug_context.target_text: ORE RESERVES . Pursuant to Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), in order to achieve the required level of confidence in the modifying factors to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, a Mining Reporting Entity will need to have carried out a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study ). The key underlying assumptions and outcomes of the Technical Study are also to be disclosed.

question: When can an Offer of Securities be an Exempt Offer if it fits more than one situation in Rule 4.3.1, and what are some examples of these situations?
expected_answer: An Offer of Securities can still be an Exempt Offer if it fits more than one situation in Rule 4.3.1, as long as the whole Offer fits at least one of those situations [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0]. Examples of these situations include offers made only to Professional Clients, offers directed at no more than 50 Persons in a year excluding certain Professional Clients, and offers where the total payment is at least $100,000 [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc].

debug_context.source_text: Subject to (2), an Offer of Securities remains an Exempt Offer even if the Offer falls in whole or part within more than one of the circumstances specified in Rule 4.3.1, as long as all of the Offer falls within at least one of those circumstances.
debug_context.target_text: For the purposes of section 61(3)(a) of the FSMR, the Regulator prescribes the following to be circumstances in which an Offer is an Exempt Offer: (1) an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients; (2) an Offer in or from the ADGM which is directed at no more than 50 Persons in any 12-month period, excluding Professional Clients who are not natural persons; (3) an Offer where the total consideration to be paid by a Person to acquire the Securities is at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (4) an Offer where the Securities are denominated in amounts of at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (5) an Offer where the total aggregate consideration for the Securities offered is less than $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency, calculated over a period of 12 months; (6) an Offer where Shares are issued in substitution for Shares of the same class as already issued, where the issue of the new Shares does not involve any increase in the issued Share capital; (7) an Offer where the Securities are Convertibles issued under a Prospectus to existing members or creditors of the Issuer or a member of its Group and there is no additional consideration to be paid; (8) an Offer where the Securities are offered in connection with a Takeover and a document is made available containing information which is considered by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (9) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a merger if a document is available containing information which is regarded by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (10) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a rights issue where: (a) the Securities are of a class subject to Reporting Entity disclosure; and (b) a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Securities including rights attaching to those Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (11) an Offer where the Shares are offered, allotted or to be allotted to existing Shareholders free of charge or dividends paid out in the form of Shares of the same class as the Shares in respect of which the dividends are paid, and a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Shares and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (12) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted to an existing or former Director or Employee, or any Close Relative of such a Director or Employee, of the Issuer or a member of the same Group as the Issuer and: (a) the Issuer or the member of the Group already has its Securities admitted to trading on a Regulated Exchange; and (b) a document is made available to the offerees containing information on the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; or (13) other than in relation to Debentures and Sukuk, an Offer in or from the ADGM which is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, in circumstances where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility.

question: How much capital must a Recognised Investment Exchange keep for its operational costs, and what counts as operational costs for an Authorised Person working with virtual assets?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must keep capital equal to six months of its operational costs, with a possible extra buffer of up to six months unless the Regulator says otherwise [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96]. For an Authorised Person dealing with virtual assets, operational costs include all necessary overheads and non-discretionary expenses, like technology-related costs, over a year, but not variable or exceptional items [#SRC:fce60db3-c326-4528-9828-e6d5bd1b98e7].

debug_context.source_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS FOR AUTHORISED PERSONS ENGAGED IN REGULATED ACTIVITIES IN RELATION TO VIRTUAL ASSETS Capital Requirements Operational expenses, as set out in MIR Rule 3.2.1, broadly includes all of the overhead, non-discretionary costs (variable and exceptional items can be excluded) incurred (or forecast to be incurred) by an Authorised Person in its operations over the course of a twelve-month period. Technology-related operational expenses, such as the use of IT servers and technology platforms, storage and usage of IT equipment and technology services required for the overall operability of the Authorised Persons platform, are to be included. Development costs, such as research and intellectual property patenting can be excluded.
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange shall hold the following capital: (a) an amount equal to 6 months' operational expenses; plus (b) unless the Regulator directs otherwise, an additional buffer amount of up to a further 6 months' operational expenses.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate the RWA for its SE Exposures, including Early Amortisation Exposures, and what are the specific steps involved in this process?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate the RWA for its SE Exposures by following a structured process. Initially, the Authorised Person must determine the value of each SE Exposure using the Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9, while considering any applicable CRM [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646]. For Early Amortisation Exposures, the same measurement methodology applies [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]. Next, the Authorised Person must allocate a Credit Quality Grade to each SE Exposure as per the Rules in Section 4.11 [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646]. The RWA for each SE Exposure is then calculated using the formula RWA(SE) = SE x CRW, where CRW is the risk weight determined by the Credit Quality Grade [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646]. For Early Amortisation Exposures, the formula RWA(EAE) = EAE x CRW is used, with CRW reflecting the risk weight as if the Exposure had not been securitised [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]. Finally, the Authorised Person must aggregate the RWA amounts for all SE Exposures, including those for Early Amortisation Exposures, to determine the total RWA [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646][#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e].

debug_context.source_text: Calculation of RWA for securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures). To calculate its RWA for all its SE Exposures, an Authorised Person must: (a) calculate the value of the Exposure for each of its SE Exposures in accordance with Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM; (b) allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade for that SE Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.11; (c) calculate the RWA amount for each SE Exposure, except for those SE Exposures which the Authorised Person is required to include as deductions from any component of Capital Resources, using the following formula: RWA(SE) = SE x CRW where: (i) "RWA(SE)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that securitisation Exposure; (ii) "SE" refers to the Exposure value or amount for that SE Exposure calculated in accordance with (a); and (iii) "CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for that SE Exposure determined in accordance with (b); and (d) add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (c) for all its SE Exposures to the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with Rule 4.8.5 in respect of its Early Amortisation Exposures.
debug_context.target_text: Calculation of RWA for securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures). To calculate its RWA for Early Amortisation Exposures, an Authorised Person must: (a) calculate the value of the Exposure (EAE) for each of its Early Amortisation Exposures in accordance with Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM; (b) calculate the risk weighted Exposure amount for each Early Amortisation Exposure using the following formula: RWA(EAE) = EAE x CRW where: (i) "RWA(EAE)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that Early Amortisation Exposure; (ii) "EAE" refers to the Exposure value or amount, for that Early Amortisation Exposure calculated in accordance with (a); and (iii) "CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for the underlying Exposure type as if the Exposure had not been securitised; and (c) add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (b) for all its Early Amortisation Exposures.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator disclose a statement made by a person to an investigator during an interview conducted pursuant to section 206(1)(a) to a law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings, and how does this relate to the Investigator's authority to require attendance at interviews?
expected_answer: The Regulator is prohibited from disclosing a statement made by a person to an investigator during an interview conducted under section 206(1)(a) to any law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings unless the person consents to the disclosure or the Regulator is required by law or court order to do so [#SRC:7585319d-2470-46fc-975e-d1a88a2805d6]. This confidentiality requirement is linked to the Investigator's authority, which includes the power to require a person to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Thus, while the Investigator can compel attendance and questioning, the subsequent use of any statements made is tightly controlled to protect the individual's confidentiality unless specific conditions are met.

debug_context.source_text: In addition to the overriding duty of confidentiality set out in section 198, section 207(2) of the FSMR prohibits the Regulator from disclosing a statement made by a person to an investigator at an interview conducted pursuant to section 206(1)(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against that person unless: (a) the person consents to the disclosure; or (b) the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.
debug_context.target_text: The Investigator may, by written notice, require the person who is the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to— (a) attend an interview at a Specified time and place and answer questions; (b) produce at a Specified time and place any Specified Documents or Documents of a Specified description; (c) provide such information as the Investigator may require; (d) provide such assistance as the Investigator may require; or (e) permit the Investigator to enter the business premises of such person during normal business hours for the purpose of inspecting and copying Documents on such premises.

question: When can a Recognised Investment Exchange allow trading of Securities that aren't on the Official List, and how does this connect to changes the Regulator might make for an Exempt Offeror?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange cannot usually allow trading of Securities unless they are on the Official List and not suspended [#TGT:76d81d0b-f659-47be-bcb8-a99a24187cac]. However, the Regulator can change some rules for an Exempt Offeror who wants to follow the Listing Rules to get its Securities on the Official List [#SRC:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc]. This change is needed because, without it, the Exempt Offeror's Securities can't be on the Official List, which is needed for trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange [#SRC:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc].

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator may also modify one or more requirements of this chapter for an Exempt Offeror who wishes to voluntarily comply with the Listing Rules in order to include its Securities on the Official List and thereby seek admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. Without such a modification an Exempt Offeror cannot have its Securities included in the Official List. This is because section 50(3) of the FSMR requires that a Recognised Investment Exchange shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List.
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List except where otherwise prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator.

question: What obligations does a Reporting Entity have to ensure Inside Information is promptly identified and disclosed, considering the extension of 'awareness' to include information that Officers ought reasonably have come into possession of?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity is obligated to implement suitable systems and procedures to promptly identify Inside Information within a Listed Entity and determine if disclosure is required [#SRC:515da637-1abc-4870-b98f-7ebda16f0984]. The concept of 'awareness' extends to include information that Officers ought reasonably have come into possession of, meaning the entity is considered 'aware' if the information is significant enough to be brought to an Officer's attention [#TGT:d437551a-aae1-4d57-94a7-fb36d8b2f879]. This extension prevents the entity from avoiding or delaying its disclosure obligations by ensuring that Inside Information is promptly communicated to Officers [#TGT:d437551a-aae1-4d57-94a7-fb36d8b2f879].

debug_context.source_text: BECOMING AWARE OF INSIDE INFORMATION In regard to Rule 7.2.1, the first question that an Officer of a Reporting Entity should therefore consider is whether the Reporting Entity is aware of any Inside Information. If yes, that Officer must consider, immediately, whether that Inside Information must be Disclosed. Suitable systems and procedures must therefore be implemented by a Reporting Entity to ensure that Inside Information is promptly identified by, or within, a Listed Entity (in light of the awareness extension discussed in paragraph 38 above) and a decision is taken as to whether a Disclosure is required.
debug_context.target_text: BECOMING AWARE OF INSIDE INFORMATION The extension of a Reporting Entity’s ‘awareness’ to include information that its Officers ‘ought reasonably have come into possession of’ (over and above information that its Officers, in fact, ‘know’) means that a Reporting Entity is considered to be ‘aware’ of Inside Information if the information is known by anyone within the Listed Entity, and is of such significance that it ought reasonably to have been brought to the attention of an Officer of the Listed Entity. Without this extension to the concept of ‘awareness’, a Reporting Entity would be able to avoid, or delay, meeting its continuous disclosure obligations in circumstances where Inside Information had not been brought to the attention of its Officers in a timely manner by others within the Listed Entity. A Listed Entity will need to ensure that it has in place internal systems, processes and controls to ensure that Inside Information is promptly brought to the attention of its Officers.

question: If an Authorised Person is doing Investment Business, what records do they need to keep in their Resolution Pack, and how does Rule 16.1 affect this?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person doing Investment Business needs to keep certain records in their Resolution Pack as required by Rule 16.1, which mandates maintaining and retrieving specific documents [#SRC:9dc5d839-07b0-4c04-9b95-1b5733012807]. These records include details about Client classification and agreements, lists of Client Accounts for Client Money and investments, and permissions for using Client Investments [#TGT:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. They also need to have assessments and acknowledgements related to Third-Party Agents and the latest reconciliations of Client Money and Investments [#TGT:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5].

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person falling within Rule 16.1 must maintain at all times and be able to retrieve, in the manner described in this chapter, the documents and records specified in Rule 16.3.1 and Rule 16.4.1 (the "Resolution Pack").
debug_context.target_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules ‎2.7.1 and ‎3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and ‎15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule ‎15.4.4 and Rule ‎15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule ‎15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and ‎15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).

question: Under what conditions may a Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund perform fund administration, and how must risk management be addressed in relation to the roles of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians?
expected_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund may perform fund administration if risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc]. Additionally, the Fund Manager must ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of the Fund are adequately addressed, considering the nature of the strategies and investment process employed. This includes taking into account the roles of Fund Administrators, Eligible Custodians, and, if applicable, prime brokers [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7].

A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund must ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of a Fund are adequately addressed, with due regard to the nature of the strategies and investment process employed by the Fund Manager and the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and where appointed, prime brokers.

question: How must a Captive Insurer value investments and positions under Rule 6.6.1, and what types of financial instruments are subject to Rule 6.6.2 for valuation purposes?
expected_answer: A Captive Insurer is required to use mark-to-market valuation to measure the value of investments and positions under Rule 6.6.1, which involves using readily available close out prices from independent sources [#SRC:d3ab7118-2ac1-4bd3-a89d-3f2776cb744f]. Rule 6.6.2 applies to the valuation of various financial instruments, including debt securities, bonds, money-market and capital-market instruments, loans, shares, variable yield participations, units in Collective Investment Funds, Derivatives, and any balance sheet positions measured at market or fair value [#TGT:7b75295d-3023-4980-9ca8-71a527649045].

debug_context.source_text: Wherever possible, a Captive Insurer must mark-to-market in order to measure the value of the investments and positions to which this Rule applies under Rule 6.6.1. Marking to market is valuation at readily available close out prices from independent sources.
debug_context.target_text: Subject to the exceptions set out in this Chapter, Rule ‎6.6.2 applies in relation to the valuation of Investments that are, or amounts arising from the disposal of: (a) debt securities, bonds and other money-market and capital-market instruments; (b) loans; (c) shares and other variable yield participations; (d) units in Collective Investment Funds; (e) Derivatives; and (f) any balance sheet position measured at market value or fair value.

question: If a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree to change the rules about refund requests, what must the Customer do to still get redress for unauthorised transactions?
expected_answer: When a Customer that is not a Natural Person agrees with a Third Party Provider to change the rules about refund requests, they may set a different time period for handling unauthorised or incorrect transactions [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. However, to get redress, the Customer must notify the Third Party Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the transaction date once they become aware of the issue [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb]. This ensures the Customer's right to redress is maintained despite any changes to the refund request rules.

debug_context.source_text: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that the following Rules do not apply: (a) Rules 20.2.15 and 20.2.16 (charges for information); (b) Rule 20.7.3 and 20.7.4 (withdrawal of consent); (c) Rule 20.8.2 (revocation of a Payment Order); (d) Rules 20.10.1 and 20.10.2 (requests for refund); (e) Rule 20.11.1 (evidence on authentication and execution); (f) Rule 20.12.5 (liability for charges); and the parties may agree that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1.
debug_context.target_text: Subject to Rule 20.10.2, a Customer is only entitled to redress if it notifies its Third Party Provider without undue delay, and in any event no later than twelve months after the date of execution, on becoming aware of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction.

question: What are the notification requirements for a Fund Manager of a Passported Fund when the Prospectus is amended or replaced, and how does this relate to the prescribed form directed by the Regulator?
expected_answer: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable, and no later than seven days after becoming aware, if the Prospectus relating to the Passported Fund has been amended or replaced [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. This notification must include reasonable detail of the event and a copy of the new Prospectus, in a form prescribed by the Regulator [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].

debug_context.source_text: The notification referred to in Rule 6.6.2 must be in such prescribed form as the Regulator may direct from time to time. At a minimum, the notification must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event and (where the Prospectus has been amended or replaced) a copy of the new Prospectus.
debug_context.target_text: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, in accordance with applicable ADGM legislation. In particular (but without limitation), a Fund Manager or the governing body or trustee of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable (and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware) of any of the following events: (a) the Fund Manager intends to retire as manager of the Passported Fund; (b) it is proposed that a successor manager will be appointed in relation to the Passported Fund; (c) the Fund Manager has been removed or replaced as manager of the Passported Fund; (d) any material service provider to the Passported Fund (including, without limitation, any custodian) or an Agent or Licensed Person resigns, is appointed, is removed, or is replaced; (e) the Prospectus relating to the Passported Fund has been amended or replaced; (f) winding-up of the Passported Fund has commenced; or (g) the Fund Manager intends to vary or revoke its Financial Service Permission (or any conditions contained in that Financial Service Permission).

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator grant waivers for Financial Instruments not covered by Rule 3.5.7, and how do these conditions relate to waivers based on market model and transaction type?
expected_answer: The Regulator may grant waivers for Financial Instruments not covered by Rule 3.5.7 under specific conditions such as when orders are large in scale compared to normal market size, when orders are held in an order management facility of the Recognised Investment Exchange pending disclosure, or when there is no liquid market for the Financial Instruments [#SRC:63e56280-5a41-48fb-a327-25aebcb4834a]. These conditions are related to waivers based on market model and transaction type, which include systems matching orders based on a reference price from another trading venue, systems formalising negotiated transactions within a volume cap, and orders large in scale as specified in Rule 3.5.11 [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6]. Both sets of conditions allow for flexibility in trading practices while ensuring that the market's integrity and price formation are not compromised.

debug_context.source_text: For Financial Instruments not covered by Rule 3.5.7, waivers may be granted by the Regulator for any of the following: (a) orders that are large in scale compared with normal market size; (b) orders held in an order management facility of the Recognised Investment Exchange pending disclosure; or (c) Financial Instruments for which there is not a liquid market.
debug_context.target_text: Waivers based on market model and type of order or transaction. Waivers from Rule 3.5.1 based on market model and transaction may be granted by the Regulator in respect of Financial Instruments, for any of the following: (a) systems matching orders based on a trading methodology by which the price of the Financial Instrument is derived from a reference price generated by another trading venue or the most relevant market in terms of liquidity, where that reference price is widely published and is regarded by Members as a reliable reference price; (b) systems that formalise negotiated transactions, which are: (i) made at, or within, the current volume weighted spread reflected on the order book or the quotes of the market makers, subject to a volume cap to be determined by the Regulator to ensure that the use of this waiver does not unduly harm price formation; (ii) where the Financial Instrument does not fall within the meaning of a liquid market, and are dealt within a percentage of a suitable reference price, being a percentage and a reference price set in advance by the Recognised Investment Exchange; or (iii) subject to conditions other than the current market price of that Financial Instrument, being; A. a transaction related to an individual Financial Instrument in a portfolio trade; or B. a volume weighted average price transaction. (c) orders that are large in scale compared with normal market size, as set out in Rule 3.5.11; or (d) orders held in an order management facility of the Recognised Investment Exchange pending disclosure.

question: When assessing a PFP Applicant's application to become authorised to carry on Regulated Activities, what conditions must the applicant satisfy to demonstrate compliance with both the Threshold Conditions and the Regulator's requirements?
expected_answer: A PFP Applicant must satisfy several conditions to demonstrate compliance with both the Threshold Conditions and the Regulator's requirements. The applicant must show that it possesses adequate and appropriate resources, including financial resources, to the satisfaction of the FSRA [#SRC:05a7c46a-5ae7-46dc-9959-0022589fb3c0]. Additionally, the applicant must be deemed fit and proper, capable of being effectively supervised, and have adequate compliance arrangements, including policies and procedures, to comply with all applicable legal requirements, including the Rules [#TGT:af65ff3c-f0e5-4696-bfa9-e84675e773cb]. These requirements ensure that the applicant is well-prepared to undertake Regulated Activities under the oversight of the Regulator.

debug_context.source_text: The Threshold Conditions set out in GEN Rule 5.2.7, require a PFP Applicant to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the FSRA that it: (a) has adequate and appropriate resources, including financial resources; (b) is fit and proper; (c) is capable of being effectively supervised; and (d) has adequate compliance arrangements, including policies and procedures, that will enable it to comply with all the applicable legal requirements.
debug_context.target_text: Consideration and assessment of applications: In order to become authorised to carry on one or more Regulated Activities, the applicant must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Regulator that it: (1) has adequate and appropriate resources, including financial resources; (2) is fit and proper; (3) is capable of being effectively supervised; and (4) has adequate compliance arrangements, including policies and procedures, that will enable it to comply with all the applicable legal requirements, including the Rules.

question: Under what circumstances must an Authorised Person pay both an application fee and a supplementary fee when applying to establish a branch outside ADGM?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person with its registered head office in ADGM must pay an application fee when applying to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM. This fee is calculated as 50% of the highest application fee specified in Chapter 3 for the Regulated Activities intended at the new branch [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f]. Additionally, a supplementary fee may be charged by the Regulator if the proposed branch is to operate in a jurisdiction lacking an adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92].

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator may charge a supplementary fee in addition to the fees specified in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2 where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding in place between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction.
debug_context.target_text: Where an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM applies to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM, it must pay to the Regulator an application fee equal to 50% of the highest application fee set out in Chapter 3 of these Rules for those Regulated Activities it seeks to undertake from the proposed branch.

question: When figuring out CET1 Capital deductions, how should an Authorised Person handle intangible assets and goodwill, especially with deferred tax liabilities and significant investments?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person needs to deduct goodwill and other intangible assets from its CET1 Capital as per the International Financial Reporting Standards [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. The deduction for intangible assets should be reduced by any deferred tax liabilities that would be eliminated if these assets were impaired or derecognised [#SRC:d1409eb5-7360-450f-b836-eb12bb12e33f]. Moreover, the deduction must include goodwill that is part of the valuation of significant investments [#SRC:d1409eb5-7360-450f-b836-eb12bb12e33f].

debug_context.source_text: CET1 Deductions - intangible assets. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(b), an Authorised Person must determine the intangible assets to be deducted in accordance with the following: (a) the amount to be deducted must be reduced by the amount of associated deferred tax liabilities that would be extinguished if the intangible assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and (b) the amount to be deducted must include goodwill included in the valuation of significant Investments of the Authorised Person.
debug_context.target_text: CET1 Deductions. Subject to the following Rules in this Section, an Authorised Person must deduct the following from the calculation of its CET1 Capital: (a) losses for the current financial year; (b) goodwill and other intangible assets as defined in the International Financial Reporting Standards; (c) deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability; (d) defined benefit pension fund assets of the Authorised Person; (e) the applicable amount, by reference to Rule 3.10.12, of direct and indirect holdings by an Authorised Person of its own CET1 Capital instruments including instruments under which an Authorised Person is under an actual or contingent obligation to effect a purchase by virtue of an existing contractual obligation; (f) holdings of the CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where those entities have a reciprocal cross holding with the Authorised Person which have the effect of artificially inflating the Capital Resources of the Authorised Person; (g) the applicable amount, by reference to Rule 3.10.13, of direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person does not have a significant investment in those entities; (h) the applicable amount, by reference to Rules 3.10.13 and 3.10.18, of direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of the CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person has a significant investment in those entities; (i) the amount of items required to be deducted from the calculation of AT1 Capital in accordance with the relevant Rules under Section 3.11, that exceeds the AT1 Capital of the Authorised Person; (j) the Exposure amount of the following items which qualify for a risk weight of 1000%, where the Authorised Person deducts that Exposure amount from CET1 Capital as an alternative to applying a risk weight of 1000%: (i) Qualifying Holdings; (ii) securitisation positions, in accordance with relevant Rules in Chapter 4; and (iii) free deliveries, in accordance with the Rules in Section A4.6; and (k) for an Authorised Person which is a Partnership, the amount by which the aggregate of the amounts withdrawn by its Partners or members exceeds the profits of that firm.

question: What records related to Third-Party Agents must an Authorised Person include in their Resolution Pack when conducting Investment Business, considering the requirements for assessing the suitability of such agents for holding Client Money?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include specific records related to Third-Party Agents in their Resolution Pack. These records include the assessment of the appropriateness of a Third-Party Agent and the acknowledgement by the Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Money, as per Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Additionally, before paying Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, the Authorised Person must have undertaken a prior assessment of the suitability of that Third-Party Agent and concluded on reasonable grounds that the agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143].

debug_context.source_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules 2.7.1 and 3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and 15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule 15.4.4 and Rule 15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule 15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and 15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person may pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent only where it has undertaken a prior assessment of the suitability of that Third-Party Agent and concluded on reasonable grounds that the Third-Party Agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account.

question: What specific additional information must a Private Credit Fund include in its periodic reports, and how does this relate to the general requirements for Funds as outlined in Rule 16.4?
expected_answer: A Private Credit Fund is required to include specific additional information in its periodic reports beyond the general requirements for Funds as outlined in Rule 16.4. This includes a detailed breakdown of originated loans by type, such as senior secured debt, junior debt, and mezzanine debt, as well as a summary of committed but undrawn Credit Facilities [#TGT:2c849a7d-71bb-4e57-acc5-fa50870faadf]. Additionally, the reports must provide a breakdown of loans by repayment schedule, the loan to value ratio for each loan, and information on non-performing exposures and forbearance activities [#TGT:2c849a7d-71bb-4e57-acc5-fa50870faadf]. Furthermore, the results of recent stress testing and any material changes to the credit assessment or monitoring process must be described [#TGT:2c849a7d-71bb-4e57-acc5-fa50870faadf]. This additional information complements the general information required by Rule 16.4, which is to be included in the periodic reports for Funds generally [#SRC:7199a7a2-6eb9-4183-b8c3-036c4c1dd5ed].

debug_context.source_text: The information described in Rule 13A.6.1 should accompany the information to be included in the periodic reports required for Funds generally as set out in Rule 16.4.
debug_context.target_text: In addition to the information required pursuant to these Rules, the periodic reports issued by a Private Credit Fund must include the following additional information: (h) a breakdown of the originated loans between senior secured debt, junior debt and mezzanine debt; (i) a summary of all committed but undrawn Credit Facilities; (j) a breakdown of the originated loans between loans made with an amortising repayment schedule and loans made with bullet repayments; (k) a breakdown of the loan to value ratio for each originated loan; (l) information in respect of non-performing exposures and exposures subject to forbearance activities; (m) a summary of the results of the most recent stress testing undertaken in accordance with Rules 13A.7.1 or 13A.7.2; and (n) a description of any material changes to the credit assessment or monitoring process of the Private Credit Fund.

question: What must a Listed Entity's Board do to make sure Debenture holders can vote by proxy when their rights or terms are being changed?
expected_answer: The Board of a Listed Entity must provide all Shareholders, including Debenture holders when they are involved, the right and means to vote by proxy at meetings where they can exercise their voting rights [#TGT:6364a6a2-b7e3-4559-8102-002850811697]. When Debenture holders are asked to vote on changes to their rights or terms, they should be treated as Shareholders according to the expectations set out in Rule 9.3.1, ensuring compliance with the relevant rules [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b].

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator will expect a Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1 to consider references to a Shareholder in this section to refer equally to holders of all classes of Securities as may be applicable in the context of the Listed Entity. For example, in a situation where holders of Debentures are to be asked to vote on a variation of rights or terms, the Regulator will expect a Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1 to give due consideration to the requirements of Rules 9.3.6 and 9.3.7 as if it referred to the relevant Debenture holders.
debug_context.target_text: Proxy solicitation. The Board of a Listed Entity must ensure that for each meeting at which Shareholders are eligible to exercise voting rights attaching to their Securities, each Shareholder is given the right and means to vote by proxy.

question: If an MTF wants to list Exempt Offer Securities, what must it do about the number of Retail Clients and the systems it uses?
expected_answer: When an MTF wants to list Exempt Offer Securities, it must follow certain rules to ensure proper trading. The MTF can allow these Securities to be traded by an unlimited number of Professional Clients and up to 200 Retail Clients, as long as these Retail Clients have been assessed to have the right knowledge and experience about the risks involved [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f]. The MTF must also have systems and controls to ensure only Securities from Exempt Offers made on its platform are admitted, identify who the Exempt Offer was made to, and limit trading to no more than 200 people who are not Professional Clients [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. It must also comply with specific trading admission rules and provide users with access to important information about the Securities [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66].

debug_context.source_text: In respect of Securities offered by Exempt Offer, whether previously offered through a PFP or not, an MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, enabling such Securities to be traded amongst an unlimited number of Professional Clients and not more than 200 Retail Clients which have been assessed by the MTF Operator to possess appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks, in accordance with Market Infrastructure Rules (MIR) Rule 2.8.3. A description of the systems and controls required to be employed by a MTF Operator that seeks to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading is set out in Conduct of Business Rules (COBS) Rule 8.2.2.
debug_context.target_text: An MTF that admits to trading Securities that are offered by way of an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13) shall ensure that it has effective systems and controls in place to: (a) admit only Securities of such Exempt Offers that are made on its own platform; (b) identify those Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made; (c) restrict trading of the Securities, to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients; (d) comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 (Admission to trading), as applicable in relation to the relevant Securities; and (e) allow users of its market to obtain Inside Information, including any Offer documents pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.5 relevant to the Securities.

question: Under what circumstances can a decision by the Regulator, which affects a person's rights or liabilities, be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review, considering both the FSMR and the Regulations?
expected_answer: A decision by the Regulator that affects a person's rights or liabilities can be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review if it meets certain conditions outlined in both the FSMR and the Regulations. According to Section 225(1) of FSMR, any decision that may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or adversely affect their interests, except for operational decisions, is eligible for referral to the Appeals Panel [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. Additionally, the Regulations specify that any decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator, or Rules made by the Regulator, which may affect a person's rights or liabilities, can also be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23]. Therefore, the combined scope of both the FSMR and the Regulations allows for a broad range of decisions to be eligible for such a review, provided they impact a person's rights or liabilities.

debug_context.source_text: Section 225(1) of FSMR provides that all of our decisions that may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person (except operational decisions) may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review. FSMR also specifies that certain other decisions, not subject to the Part 21 procedure, may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review (e.g., exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers).
debug_context.target_text: Any decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator or Rules made by the Regulator which may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person, may be referred by that person to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review .

question: How does the irrevocability of a Payment Order for a Low Value Payment Instrument after consent is given relate to the general refusal notification requirements for Payment Orders?
expected_answer: For a Low Value Payment Instrument, once the Payer has transmitted the Payment Order or given consent to execute the Payment Transaction, the Payment Order may not be revoked [#SRC:a0213781-cf1e-47ae-befc-8e10afd8e60d]. In contrast, generally, if a Payment Service Provider refuses to execute a Payment Order, it must notify the Payment Service User at the earliest opportunity and, if possible, provide reasons for the refusal, including any procedure for correcting factual errors [#TGT:7c2360b7-d85f-4ec3-97e2-e91cb6e4ae40]. This irrevocability highlights a specific condition under which the general refusal notification requirements may not be applicable.

debug_context.source_text: In the case of a Payment Order relating to a Low Value Payment Instrument: (a) a Payment Service Provider is not required to notify the Payment Service User of the refusal of a Payment Order relating to such Low Value Payment Instrument and the reasons for such refusal in accordance with Rule 19.14.2(1) if the non-execution is apparent from the context; (b) the Payer may not revoke the Payment Order under Rule 19.14.3 after transmitting the Payment Order or giving its consent to execute the Payment Transaction to the Payee; (c) execution periods other than those provided by Rule 19.15.2 may apply.
debug_context.target_text: Refusal of Payment Orders. Where a Payment Service Provider refuses to execute a Payment Order or to initiate a Payment Transaction, it must notify the Payment Service User at the earliest opportunity in the agreed manner of the refusal, and, if possible, the reasons for such refusal, including, if applicable, the procedure for rectifying any factual errors that led to the refusal.

question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative provided by an MDB, and how must the risk weight for any CR Exposure in the MDB asset class be determined?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative provided by a Multilateral Development Bank (MDB) if the MDB is referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9 [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b]. For any CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, the Authorised Person must apply risk weights according to the specified table, which assigns a 0% risk weight for Credit Quality Grade 1, 50% for Grades 2 and 3, 100% for Grades 4 and 5, 150% for Grade 6, and 50% for unrated exposures [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c].

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative only if it is provided by any of the following entities: (a) central government or central bank; (b) MDB referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9; (c) International Organisations referred to in Rule 4.12.9; (d) PSE; (e) banks and Securities firms which qualify for inclusion in bank asset class; or (f) any other entity that has an external credit assessment from a recognised credit rating agency that maps to a Credit Quality Grade 3 or better.
debug_context.target_text: Multilateral development bank (MDB) asset class. Subject to Rules 4.12.8 and 4.12.9, an Authorised Person must risk weight any CR Exposure in the MDB asset class in accordance with the following table: Risk Weights for the MDB asset class /Table Start Credit Quality Grade 1 2 3 4 5 6 Unrated Risk Weight 0% 50% 50% 100% 100% 150% 50% /Table End

question: When an Authorised Person takes eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, how do they figure out the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure if there's no qualifying cross product Netting agreement?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person needs to calculate the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure by using the latest fair value of Securities lent or sold, or the cash amount lent or paid, depending on the type of SFT, when there is no qualifying cross product Netting agreement [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e]. If eligible financial Collateral is involved, the Authorised Person can adjust the exposure measurement by following specific rules, namely Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20, which allow for recognising the effect of the Collateral [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. This approach ensures that both the type of transaction and the presence of Collateral are considered.

debug_context.source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
debug_context.target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must determine E, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT which is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement as follows: (a) in the case where the Authorised Person has lent Securities to a Counterparty or sold Securities to a Counterparty with a commitment to repurchase those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold; and (b) in the case where the Authorised Person has lent cash to a Counterparty through the borrowing of Securities from the Counterparty or paid cash for the purchase of Securities from a Counterparty with a commitment to resell those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the amount of cash lent or paid.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator require a Person to pay a supplementary fee, and how do complexity and novelty factor into this requirement?
expected_answer: The Regulator may require a Person to pay a supplementary fee when it anticipates incurring substantial additional costs or effort in handling an application, authorisation, filing, or during ongoing supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Additionally, if a request for a waiver or modification is deemed particularly complex or novel by the Regulator, this may also trigger the requirement for a supplementary fee [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404].

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate and maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital, considering both the general buffer requirement and the Countercyclical Capital Buffer specific to jurisdictional exposures?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is required to maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, which involves calculating the buffer in accordance with Rule 3.18.4 [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital. This is determined by multiplying the Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, as per Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8 [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c].

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, as calculated in accordance with Rule 3.18.4.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.

question: When can the Regulator ask for more money on top of the $1,000 fee for a new Controller or change in Holding?
expected_answer: The Regulator can ask for more money on top of the $1,000 fee if the Controller is from a place without a proper agreement with the Regulator, or if they want to change the business model, activities, or senior managers of the Authorised Person or Recognised Body [#SRC:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. More money can also be required if the application is very complex and needs extra work or costs [#SRC:52aec909-944f-40b5-b9ca-9b0d89d985df]. The $1,000 fee is for applying for a new Controller or a change in Holding [#TGT:db5cfcd0-4783-4652-b75b-d9eee44a9873].

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator may charge a supplementary fee in addition to the fee specified in Rule 6.1.1 where: a. the Controller is from a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding in place between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction; b. the Controller proposes, in connection with their approval, to change the business model, business activities, or senior management of the Authorised Person or Recognised Body; or c. the application will otherwise require the Regulator to incur substantial additional expense or expend substantial additional effort due to its complexity.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person or a Recognised Body applying for written approval of a proposed new Controller, or a change in the Holding of an existing Controller which would trigger the requirement to seek the approval of the Regulator, must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $1,000.

question: What procedures must a Recognised Clearing House implement to ensure compliance with Rule 4.5.9 regarding the designation of Persons or descriptions of persons, and how does this relate to the potential impact on market operations?
expected_answer: A Recognised Clearing House must implement procedures to designate Persons or descriptions of persons in accordance with Rule 4.5.9, ensuring that any failure by these Persons to meet their obligations does not adversely affect market operations [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b]. These procedures must include designating the relevant Persons or descriptions of persons, reviewing their designation status, and withdrawing such designations when necessary [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d].

debug_context.source_text: The procedures in Rule 4.5.9 must be designed to ensure that: (a) a Person is not, or does not remain, designated if failure by him to meet his obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would adversely affect the operation of the market; and (b) a description of persons is not, or does not remain, designated if failure by a Person of that description to meet his obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would affect operation of the market.
debug_context.target_text: If such provision is made as allowed under Rule 4.5.8, the Recognised Clearing House must have adequate procedures for: (a) designating the Persons, or descriptions of person, in respect of whom action may be taken; (b) keeping under review the question which Persons or descriptions of person should be or remain so designated; and (c) withdrawing such designation.

question: What are the record-keeping obligations of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business concerning Client classification and agreements, and how do these relate to the procedures and notices required under the applicable Rules?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include records of Client classification and Client agreements in their Resolution Pack as per Rules 2.7.1 and 3.7.1(d) [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Additionally, they are required to maintain records of the procedures followed under these Rules, including documents evidencing the Client's classification [#TGT:9c409857-238c-4ad8-b88b-6e770b674f27]. Furthermore, any notice sent to the Client pursuant to these Rules, along with evidence of despatch, must also be recorded [#TGT:9c409857-238c-4ad8-b88b-6e770b674f27]. This comprehensive record-keeping ensures compliance with both the specific requirements for Client classification and agreements and the broader procedural and notification obligations.

debug_context.source_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules 2.7.1 and 3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and 15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule 15.4.4 and Rule 15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule 15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and 15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).
debug_context.target_text: In addition to any applicable rules under GEN relating to record keeping, and the remainder of these Rules, an Authorised Person must keep records of: (a) the procedures which it has followed under these Rules, including any documents which evidence the Client's classification; and (b) any notice sent to the Client pursuant to these Rules and evidence of despatch.

question: When does an Authorised Person not have to calculate the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement for foreign currencies and gold?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person does not need to calculate the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement if certain conditions are met. The Foreign Currency business, which is the larger of the total gross long or short positions in all Foreign Currencies, must not be more than 100% of its Capital Resources [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97]. Also, the overall net open position must not be more than 2% of its Capital Resources [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97]. These conditions apply to exposures under any Islamic Contract involving foreign currencies and gold [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696].

debug_context.source_text: Market risk. An Authorised Person which is exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract, must calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with PRU Rule 5.6.2.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person need not calculate a Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement if: (a) its Foreign Currency business, defined as the greater of the sum of its gross long positions and the sum of its gross short positions in all Foreign Currencies, does not exceed 100% of Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3; and (b) its overall net open position as defined in Rule A6.4.4 does not exceed 2% of its Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3.

question: How should the Board of a Reporting Entity ensure effective communication with stakeholders while maintaining accurate financial reporting, considering the requirements for internal risk control and reporting?
expected_answer: The Board of a Reporting Entity must establish adequate communication channels with key stakeholders, such as Employees, creditors, and business Customers, tailored to the nature, scale, and complexity of its operations [#SRC:f0993ae8-64f6-44fa-a056-2c60870e6d44]. Concurrently, the Board is required to ensure that the Reporting Entity's financial and other reports provide an accurate, balanced, and understandable assessment of its financial position and prospects [#SRC:f0993ae8-64f6-44fa-a056-2c60870e6d44]. This is achieved by implementing effective internal risk control and reporting requirements [#TGT:15ba7268-fa59-4391-9785-a7066b1818f6]. The Board should also determine the level of information to be disclosed to the public or specific stakeholder groups and utilize appropriate channels, such as the company's website, for dissemination [#SRC:f0993ae8-64f6-44fa-a056-2c60870e6d44].

debug_context.source_text: Other stakeholders. While Shareholders of the Reporting Entity form the major stakeholder group of the Reporting Entity, the Board should also ensure that there are adequate channels of communication with its other key stakeholders as appropriate to the nature, scale and complexity of its business operations, and the environment in which it operates. Such stakeholders may include Employees, creditors and business Customers of the Reporting Entity. The Board should make an assessment of the level of information that should generally be made available to the public, or to any particular group of stakeholders, relating to the affairs of the Company, and how best to make use of its website or any other channels of communication as appropriate to disseminate relevant information. Principle 6 Position and prospects Rule 9.2.8 "The Board must ensure that the Reporting Entity's financial and other reports present an accurate, balanced and understandable assessment of the Reporting Entity's financial position and prospects by ensuring that there are effective internal risk control and reporting requirements."
debug_context.target_text: Principle 6 – Position and prospects. The Board must ensure that the Listed Entity's financial and other reports present an accurate, balanced and understandable assessment of the Listed Entity's financial position and prospects by ensuring that there are effective internal risk control and reporting requirements.

question: What steps must an Authorised Person take to classify someone as a Market Counterparty, including both the rules about being a Professional Client and the need for written notice?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may classify someone as a Market Counterparty if that person qualifies as a deemed Professional Client according to Rule 2.4.2 and meets the requirements in Rule 2.5(b) [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413]. Before doing so, the Authorised Person must provide the person with a written notice about the classification, which can apply to a specific Regulated Activity or all such activities [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. The person must not have asked to be classified differently within the time given in the notice [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3].

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person may classify a Person as a Market Counterparty if: (i) that Person qualifies as a deemed Professional Client in accordance with Rule 2.4.2; and (ii) the requirements in Rule 2.5(b) have been met.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person must, before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty, ensure that such a Person has: (i) been given a prior written notification of the classification as a Market Counterparty in relation to a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction, or in respect of all Regulated Activities and Transactions; and (ii) not requested to be classified otherwise within the period specified in the notice.

question: Under what conditions is a Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund exempt from appointing a third party for the Green Fund Attestation Requirement, and how does this relate to the alignment with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy?
expected_answer: A Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund is exempt from appointing a third party for the Green Fund Attestation Requirement if the fund qualifies as a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager chooses to provide the attestation itself, or if all Eligible Green Fund Assets are included in or track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]. However, the Green Fund Attestation Requirement applies specifically to the portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy, as per Rule 20.2.3(a) [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1].

debug_context.source_text: The Green Fund Attestation Requirement. Subject to Rule 20.2.9, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually. This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule 20.2.3(a). This is referred to as the Green Fund Attestation Requirement.
debug_context.target_text: Alternative Attestation Requirement. The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund is not required to appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement if: (a) the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself; or (b) all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark pursuant to Rule ‎20.2.3(b), in which event an attestation is not required.

question: What are the obligations of a Third Party Provider regarding the availability and accessibility of information related to dispute resolution services and the Governing Contract?
expected_answer: A Third Party Provider is required to ensure that information about dispute resolution services is made available to the Customer in a clear, comprehensive, and easily accessible form [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0]. Additionally, the information specified under Rule 20.13.3 must be available on the website of the Third Party Provider, at its main office and branches, and included in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414].

debug_context.source_text: The information to be made available under Rule 20.13.3 must be made available: (a) on the website of the Third Party Provider; (b) at the main office and any branches of the Third Party Provider; and (c) in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract.
debug_context.target_text: A Third Party Provider must make available to the Customer the details of the dispute resolution services able to deal with disputes concerning the rights and obligations arising under this Chapter in a clear, comprehensive and easily accessible form.

question: How must a Listed Entity report on its compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles under Rule 9.2.10, and what specific disclosures are required if the best practice standards in APP 4 are not fully adopted?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity must include in its annual financial report a statement on whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4, known as the Corporate Governance Principles, have been adopted [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. If these standards are not fully adopted, the Listed Entity is required to explain why the standards were not fully or only partially adopted and describe any actions taken to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. This aligns with the 'comply or explain' approach reflected in Rule 9.2.10, which is adopted by the Regulator concerning these principles [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72]. Additionally, the report must include a statement by the Directors on whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance, supported by relevant information and assumptions [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e].

debug_context.source_text: Rule 9.2.10 reflects the "comply or explain" approach adopted by the Regulator in respect of the Corporate Governance Principles.
debug_context.target_text: Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must: (1) state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity; (2) if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain: (a) why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and (b) what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and (3) include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: Under what conditions does Price Stabilisation not contravene section 92, and how does this relate to Market Abuse exemptions?
expected_answer: Price Stabilisation does not contravene section 92 if it is conducted in accordance with MKT 6.2, which outlines the necessary Rules for such activities [#SRC:6befa69b-50a0-463a-bf02-9fdaa4ed741e]. Additionally, behaviour that conforms with the Price Stabilisation Rules is exempt from being classified as Market Abuse under these Regulations [#TGT:89c2648f-fb2a-4194-997f-a5d6d4f074a1]. Therefore, adherence to MKT 6.2 not only ensures compliance with section 92 but also provides protection against Market Abuse allegations.

debug_context.source_text: Price Stabilisation. The effect of section 93(3)(b) is that if a Person establishes that they carried out Price Stabilisation in accordance with MKT 6.2, this conduct will not contravene section 92. MKT 6.2 sets out the relevant Rules relating to carrying on Price Stabilisation that must be complied with.
debug_context.target_text: Behaviour does not amount to Market Abuse for the purposes of these Regulations if— (a) it conforms with a Rule which includes a provision to the effect that Behaviour conforming with the Rule does not amount to Market Abuse; (b) it conforms with the Price Stabilisation Rules; or (c) it is done by a person acting on behalf of a public authority in the legitimate exercise of its public functions.

question: How must an Authorised Person handle the deduction of capital instruments from AT1 and T2 Capital when dealing with reciprocal cross-holdings with Relevant Entities, and what are the implications for capital resources?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is required to deduct holdings of both AT1 and T2 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities when there is a reciprocal cross-holding arrangement that artificially inflates the Capital Resources of the Authorised Person. For AT1 Capital, this deduction is necessary to prevent the inflation of capital resources through such reciprocal arrangements [#SRC:3bd61854-86d4-427f-9af0-54918b0e84c8]. Similarly, for T2 Capital, the deduction of holdings in reciprocal cross-holdings is mandated to ensure that the capital resources are not artificially inflated [#TGT:5e7bdc23-7d1f-4fc2-8c33-dca7595021ab]. These deductions are crucial to maintain the integrity of the capital calculations and ensure that the Authorised Person's capital resources reflect genuine financial strength.

debug_context.source_text: AT1 Deductions. Subject to the following Rules in this Section, an Authorised Person must deduct the following from the calculation of its AT1 Capital: (a) direct and indirect holdings by an Authorised Person of own AT1 Capital instruments including instruments under which an Authorised Person is under an actual or contingent obligation to effect a purchase by virtue of an existing contractual obligation; (b) holdings of the AT1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where those entities have a reciprocal cross-holding with the Authorised Person which have the effect of artificially inflating the Capital Resources of the Authorised Person; (c) the amount determined in accordance with Rule 3.11.8 of direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of the AT1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person does not have a significant investment in those entities; (d) direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of the AT1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person has a significant investment in those entities, excluding Underwriting positions held for five working days or fewer; and (e) the amounts required to be deducted from T2 Capital pursuant to Rule 3.12.4 that exceed the T2 Capital of the Authorised Person.
debug_context.target_text: T2 regulatory deductions and exclusions. Subject to the following Rules in this Section, an Authorised Person must deduct the following from the calculation of its T2 Capital: (a) direct and indirect holdings by an Authorised Person of own T2 Capital instruments, including own T2 instruments that an Authorised Person could be obliged to purchase as a result of existing contractual obligations; (b) holdings of the T2 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where those entities have a reciprocal cross holding with the Authorised Person which have the effect of artificially inflating the Capital Resources of the Authorised Person; (c) the amount of direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of the T2 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person does not have a significant investment in those entities; and (d) direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of the T2 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person has a significant investment in those entities, excluding Underwriting positions held for fewer than five working days.
